Posts.Content: I have been on a monthly IV of Zometa since May of 2007.  At that time I was on chemo, but since November I have been off chemo but take a daily pill of Femara.  The first time (and possibly) second time you get Zometa, you can have a terrible reaction.  My first dosage I was very sick to my stomach and couldn't get out of bed for a couple of days after.  I also ran a high temperature.  But after about 2 treatments, I do fine with it.  I think it builds up in your system over time.  Now I know that about 2 days after treatment, I may be sore and achy -- but a Tylenol Arthritis and a nap usually takes care of it.     I hope that you find a solution to your pain.
Posts.Title: Arimidex and Zometa

Posts.Content: I think Kimberly said it all in her response.  It was beautifully written.  Rest assured that this site has a huge group of supporters whenever you need them.  Best of luck with your biopsy -- you will be receiving many prayers on your behalf from this site!   Cindy
Posts.Title: Emotional Support

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your response.  Is Avemar something I can find at a local health food store? Coincidentally, I have an 85-year old mother who has never taken prescription drugs in her life.  She takes an aspirin a day and she does always have raw wheat germ on her cereal each morning.  She is totally healthy and lives on her own independently.  4 of her brothers and sisters have been killed by cancer.  I wonder if her eating this wheat germ her entire adult life has protected her from it?  Interesting thought.  Again, thanks for your response.   Cindy
Posts.Title: Femara treatment

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply. I haven't taken my Femara for 2 days and already feel like "myself" for the first time in months. I promised my husband to start it again. But was just hoping that their was something new outg there. Truly wondering how fast or if my cancer would spread if I didn't go back on it. But I am not a good gambler!
Posts.Title: Femara treatment

Posts.Content: This is my first post to this site.  April 2007 I went to the hospital with a terrible back spasm, and found out that I had metastatic cancer in my back with an unknown primary.  I had had no symptoms prior to my back spasm.  I went through chemo from May - November 2007.  After having more MRI and Pet scans, it showed that the cancer was still there, but had not spread.  So at that time the doctor started me on Femara and Zometa.   It is hard to find a site that addresses cancer of unknown primaries.  But the doctor is "guessing" that my cancer is breast cancer since it is responding to the Femara.   Like just about everyone on this site, I have had side effects from the Femara (weight gain, bloating, fatigue, and especially joint soreness).   I was wondering if there are any new drugs or treatments that have come out recently that can replace Femara -- without the side effects.   Thanks!
Posts.Title: Femara treatment

Posts.Content: I have stage IV metastatic breast cancer.  Since March 2007 I have been on different chemos and treatments.  I was on the estrogen suppressant Femara for one year.  When my cancer became active again, my doctor switched me to Aromasin.  I too experienced terrible joint pain.  It took great effort just to get up from a chair -- once I got walking, I was usually OK.  But my ankle, knee and wrist pain was bad.  I was actually happy when my doctor took me off of this and put me on chemo (Xeloda) -- the pain in my joints went away and I felt like I could walk again.  I relate to your comment about "having to work to keep the insurance."  I'm in the same boat.  Then to top it off, my husband was laid off from work a year and a half ago, and still hasn't been able to find a job.  So I really have to keep the insurance, now for both of us.  So sad that in the United States medical costs are so unbearable.  I thought Obama was going to make a positive change in this -- but I don't believe it any longer. Stay strong! Cindy
Posts.Title: Side Effects From Aromasin

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with Stage IV metastatic breast cancer in March 2007.  After going through the initial chemo treatment, I went on Femara for 18 months.  When that stopped working the doctor switched me to Aromasin.  I was only on it for 6 months but I have to say it felt like every bone in my body ached from it.  They took me off because it also wasn't working for me and I had to go onto an oral chemo, Xeloda.  But I feel better on the Xeloda than I did on Aromasin.  I love to walk, but while on Aromasin even my daily walk was a chore, not a pleasure.  My next pet scan is scheduled for May.  If my cancer has started to spread again and they need to put me on another new treatment -- I don't think I'd want to go back onto an estrogen suppressent.  I just felt too crummy on them.
Posts.Title: Side Effects From Aromasin

Posts.Content: I have had (or been aware I have) stage IV metastatic breast cancer since March 2007.  I have tumors on my spine, shoulder and a spot on my ribs.  Other than occasional bone aches, I am doing well.  So yes, there is plenty of hope.  I have been on difference chemo treatments (carboplatin, gemzar), hormonal suppressants, Zometa for bone strength.  For a year now I have been taking oral chemo Xeloda.  About 2 months ago, they added Avastin to my schedule.  My next MRI will be at the end of this month -- but I have to say I am doing well.  Most of my uncomfort is due to the treatment; not the cancer.  My doctor keeps saying that when one treatment stops working -- he'll find another one that will!  So hang in there, they are making medical advances for cancer each and every day.
Posts.Title: bone cancer

Posts.Content: I too have a very similar story.  Went to the hospital in March 2007 with back spasms.  Sent me home with pain killers.  I came back 2 weeks later and they decided to take an MRI.  Tumors along my spine, on my shoulders, and to my hip.  At first it was diagnosed as unknown primary -- but after 3 biopsies to my bone, they finally said it was stage IV metastatic breast cancer.  Had always gotten my mammograms and nothing (to this day) has ever shown up in my breasts.  Every time a treatment stops working, they try another one to keep it contained.  I started with Gemzar and Carboplatin and Zometa.  I am still on Zometa.  In between, tried estrogen suppressants.  For the past year I have been on oral chemo, Xeloda.  Then when the cancer showed activitiy again, they added Avastin in June.  My next pet scan is scheduled for late August 2010.  I am truly blessed to be pain free most of the time and am still working full-time (a good thing since my husband was laid off a year ago and not found a job yet -- so I carry the insurance policy).  And on June 18, my first grandchild was born.  I am so lucky to get to babysit once a week.  I just hope that they continue to find new drugs to treat the cancer.  Like I said, every time one medication stops -- there seems to be another one in the wings.
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: Sorry it took me awhile to reply.  I went for my follow-up with my doctor on Monday.  I was concerned that I may have to go back on chemo for awhile.  But instead he is just changing my oral hormone-repressing drug from Femara to Aromasin.  In mid-July I'll have another Pet scan to see if this drug is working.   I still do get Zometa via IV every 4-6 weeks.  I have been getting it since July 2007.  The doctor says he'll continue with Zometa unless I start having problems with it (sometimes you can get jaw related problems after long-term use).  My Zometa is given to me through a port I have in my chest.  They just had to replace my original port that I got back in October 2007 because it wasn't working any longer.  So now I have a newer version called a power port.  We used it for the first time on Monday and it worked like a charm.  The veins in my arm are pretty narrow -- so the nurses have a hard time using a regular IV.  That's why I got the port in the first place.  But it is alo nice because the IV time takes less through a port and if you are getting any chemo, you don't have any of that burning sensation you get from some chemos when you have it delivered in your veins.  Keep me posted on your journey.   Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Hi Deb,  I saw that you posted your message in 2003 -- and I am hoping that you are doing fine.  I just had to send a message because I feel exactly like you do in your email.  I have Stage IV metastatic cancer in the bone with an unknown primary.  I too am on Femara and Zometa.  I have been having PET scans every 6 months and so far everything has remained stable (it hasn't spread).  But I feel like the doctor doesn't really tell me anything.  I would like to know how long this continues, before it does spread.  What should I expect?  I just feel like I am in a stage of limbo. God Bless --  Cindy
Posts.Title: Metastatic Cancer in Bone

Posts.Content: I have metastatic cancer (back) with an unknown primary, but they are treating it as breast cancer.  I had chemo and am now on Femara daily and Zometa once a month. I find that my join pain is the worst first thing in the morning upon waking.  It helps if I do stretches in bed before even trying to get out.  The best exercise I have found is walking each evening.  I start out stiff -- but as I walk I before more and more fluid.  I also do some stretches and a little dumbbell work, but I have to be very careful with my back, so it limits the exercises that I can do.   I wish I had an alternative to the Femara, but don't know if there is another drug out there with less side effects.
Posts.Title: Aromasin / Femara

Posts.Content: I have metastatic carcenoma unknown primary - stage 4.  It was diagnosed in March 2007.  I went to the hospital ER which a terrible back spasm and they found the cancer up and down my verebrae from the PET scan.  It was a complete shock.  At the time they told me I may have as little as 2 - 6 months to live. I was treated with Gemstar and Carboplatin and also monthly Zometa.  I did great on this treatment.  I was able to stop chemo and began taking Femara (continuing with the Zometa) and actually have been back at work for the last 18 months with very little back pain.   But last week on my follow-up Pet Scan, it is showing that the cancer is active again and has spread to my left hip and lower lumbar.  I just finished a battery of more tests and another biopsy.  I am hoping that they find the primary site this time.  They are leaning toward breast cancer since the cancer responded to the Femara for 2 years.  I am now taking Aromasin with Zometa (instead of Femara) I just try to live each day as a gift. I'll get all my test results back June 1 and will then find out if I have to go back on chemo for a bit (hoping not).   It's hard because my husband just lost his job (after 37 years working at the same place).  He is now 58 and is looking for a new job mainly for the health benefits.  I can carry my own benefits through work -- but with the cancer back, I have no idea how long I'll be able to keep working full-time.  It is a difficult time right now but we are trying to stay positive.  This site is nice because you understand that "you are not alone" in your fight -- there are others who are fighting just as hard ... or harder.  Sometimes you just can't understand the "why" of things and I think you have to force yourself to accept Faith.  Everyone is on this earth to "die" -- it is how you live your life while alive that counts.
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Sorry it took me awhile to reply.  I went for my follow-up with my doctor on Monday.  I was concerned that I may have to go back on chemo for awhile.  But instead he is just changing my oral hormone-repressing drug from Femara to Aromasin.  In mid-July I'll have another Pet scan to see if this drug is working.   I still do get Zometa via IV every 4-6 weeks.  I have been getting it since July 2007.  The doctor says he'll continue with Zometa unless I start having problems with it (sometimes you can get jaw related problems after long-term use).  My Zometa is given to me through a port I have in my chest.  They just had to replace my original port that I got back in October 2007 because it wasn't working any longer.  So now I have a newer version called a power port.  We used it for the first time on Monday and it worked like a charm.  The veins in my arm are pretty narrow -- so the nurses have a hard time using a regular IV.  That's why I got the port in the first place.  But it is alo nice because the IV time takes less through a port and if you are getting any chemo, you don't have any of that burning sensation you get from some chemos when you have it delivered in your veins.  Keep me posted on your journey.   Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Darlene,  Loved your message -- thank you for showing such strong faith. I try to accept things, but you know, we all have those dark nights where the doubts come back.  Funny you mentioned the chiropracter.  Two days before I went to the hospital with back spasms (and found out about the cancer) I had been to a chriopracter.  He did not take x-rays and told me he knew exactly what the problem was, etc.  I went through an adjustment session and yikes, my back felt terrible.  He told me that was normal and to come back the next day.  I did and received another treatment, which made things worse.  The next day is when I went to the hospital.  So I think your doctor is right on this.  When you have growths on your back, I don't think chiropractic treatment is good.  Plus, I know for me they are worried about the bone retaining its strength (that's why I take the Zometa).  Good luck and let's try to keep in touch during our "adventure."  Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Hi there, Trying to get used to the new format here.  Not sure I like it, but I am always resistant to change! Just checking in on you.  I am fine.  The doctor scheduled my next Pet Scan and MRI for the day before and the day after Thanksging.  I'll get me results Dec. 1.  So hopefully I'll have a nice Christmas present. OK -- going to go back and try to figure out this new site.  Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Darlene,  Our cases seem very similar.  It will be nice to keep in touch and let each other know how we're progressing. And, I was thinking the same thing as you -- it is a share to waste these expensive prescription drugs.  I have about a month's worth of Femara left also and just asked my doctor if there was someone I could give it to.  He said that legally he wasn't allowed to pass on any opened prescriptions, but if I knew of a friend who needed it, I could give it to them.   If I continue to use Aromasin I will let you know and maybe I could use your extra prescriptions.  I won't know until mid-July is the doctor will continue to keep me on it.  And, I wonder why I haven't been sent for any radiation.  My cancer is also in the vertabrae.  I'll have to ask my doctor.  I am 55 years old and still working (to keep the insurance benefits).  My husband who is 58 was just laid off from a job he had for 37 years.  So I have to stay healthy enough to carry the medical benefits until he hits 65 and can get Medicare.  That just isn't right that your medical benefits are so connected to your job.   And, we also have a back yard full of bird feeders.  We love to watch all the different types of birds that pass through our yard.  What part of the country due you live in?  Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: As long as you post to this website, you'll never be a Lone Ranger.  There are so many good people answering these posts who will be a support to you.  I was on Femara for a year.  After that my metastatic breast cancer began to show new activity, so in May I was switched to Aromasin.  I have noticed the joint pain, stiffness, and weight gain -- but I haven't noticed any hair thinning.  But I know that everyone reacts differently to treatments.   Hopefully they will come out with a new medication one day without these awful side effects.  Meantime, we need to keep our hopes high!
Posts.Title: Hair Thinning Problems

Posts.Content: This is my second reply to your message.  I was switched from Femara to Aromasin in June.  When I first read your message, my hair was fine.  But during the last few weeks I have noticed a lot of hair loss and thinning just like you are experiencing.  My bathroom counters are covered in hair each time I brush or blow dry it.  It reminds me of when I was first diagnosed and was on chemo (Gemstar).  I didn't lose all my hair but it thinned out extremely.   I haven't been happy with the side effects of Aromasin.  My next doctor appointment is on August 10th.  I am going to discuss different options with him at that time. Let me know if you decide to change medication and you find one that you adjust to better.   Cindy
Posts.Title: Hair Thinning Problems

Posts.Content: Darlene,  Our cases seem very similar.  It will be nice to keep in touch and let each other know how we're progressing. And, I was thinking the same thing as you -- it is a share to waste these expensive prescription drugs.  I have about a month's worth of Femara left also and just asked my doctor if there was someone I could give it to.  He said that legally he wasn't allowed to pass on any opened prescriptions, but if I knew of a friend who needed it, I could give it to them.   If I continue to use Aromasin I will let you know and maybe I could use your extra prescriptions.  I won't know until mid-July is the doctor will continue to keep me on it.  And, I wonder why I haven't been sent for any radiation.  My cancer is also in the vertabrae.  I'll have to ask my doctor.  I am 55 years old and still working (to keep the insurance benefits).  My husband who is 58 was just laid off from a job he had for 37 years.  So I have to stay healthy enough to carry the medical benefits until he hits 65 and can get Medicare.  That just isn't right that your medical benefits are so connected to your job.   And, we also have a back yard full of bird feeders.  We love to watch all the different types of birds that pass through our yard.  What part of the country due you live in?  Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Hi there, Trying to get used to the new format here.  Not sure I like it, but I am always resistant to change! Just checking in on you.  I am fine.  The doctor scheduled my next Pet Scan and MRI for the day before and the day after Thanksging.  I'll get me results Dec. 1.  So hopefully I'll have a nice Christmas present. OK -- going to go back and try to figure out this new site.  Cindy
Posts.Title: It has returned now in my vertebrae

Posts.Content: Yes, there is always hope.  I was just like your mother in that I always had annual mammograms -- and they always came back clear.  Then in March 2007 I had terrible back pains and had to go to emergency.  They discovered that I had 4th stage metastatic breast cancer.  My lesions are all along my spine. (To this day, nothing has ever shown up in my breasts.  The random cancer cell that was once there traveled through my blood stream to my bones.)  They gave me 2 months to one year to live.  Here it is September 2009 and I am not only alive but back to work full-time.  I of course, still have the cancer; I have to think of it as a chronic condition.  I have chemo off and on and also get treatments of Zometa for my bones; but it is something I've learned to live with.   So you have lots of hope for your mother.  Don't let her give up the fight!! Cindy
Posts.Title: I need some support
